titlestmt.titleproper: Smith-Houston-Ogden family papers. Lawrence M.C. and Eleanor Houston Smith papers (series 74) 1860-1986 1933-1986
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Smith-Houston-Ogden family papers. Lawrence M.C. and Eleanor Houston Smith papers (series 74)

bioghist.p: Lawrence Meredith Clemson Smith (1902-1975) was a U.S. government official and Philadelphia civic leader. He was the chairman of the Philadelphia Board of Trade and Conventions from 1955 to 1963 and the U.S. vice-chairman of UNESCO. His wife, Eleanor Houston Smith (1910-1987 was a Distinguished Daughter of Pennsylvania, served two terms on the Historical Commission of Pennsylvania, and was a longtime member of the Board of Governors of the Nature Conservancy. Lawrence and Eleanor were early conservationists and helped to establish the Schuylkill Valley Nature Center. They had six children.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Lawrence M. C. Smith and Eleanor Houston Smith. Materials include: correspondence with family and friends; invitations; greeting cards; inventories, appraisals, bills and receipts, and photographs related to works of art, furniture, books and manuscripts, jewelry, silver, maps, and globes collected by the Smiths; correspondence, minutes, annual reports, newsletters, and clippings related to various projects supported by the Smiths, including the Schuylkill Valley Nature Center and the Clarke-Watson House; and architectural drawings, photographs, clippings, and accounts related to various Smith family residences. The collection also includes correspondence related to the Smiths' offer to take in English children during World War II and FBI files on Lawrence and Eleanor.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
